SPEED TEST · REAL DATA

30 Seconds vs 3 Minutes Doesn't Matter

Tested 8 AI builders with identical prompts. Durable won: 28 seconds. Webflow took 4 minutes. But when I measured total time to publish-ready site? Webflow was 2x faster. The speed marketing? It's measuring the wrong thing. Here's what nobody tells you about AI builder speed.

Testing Methodology

8
Builders tested
127
Sites generated
2-4h
Avg editing time
64m
Fastest total

My Experience

Marketing Director Sarah - Demo Impressed, Client Disappointed

THE BEFORE

Marketing director Sarah needed to demo AI website building to executive team. "Show them how fast this is." Used Durable. "Watch this." 28 seconds later: complete website on screen. Room went quiet. "Whoa," CEO said. Demo nailed it. Approved budget. But here's the problem: the demo site looked generic. CEO: "That template is fine for testing, but our brand needs custom design." Sarah: "Absolutely, we'll customize." Reality: Durable's template is locked. 2 weeks later, site still looks generic. Client asks: "Why does it look like a template?" Sarah: "It's... flexible."

THE FIX

Pivoted to Webflow. Took 4 minutes to generate. Design was stunning—minimal, modern, on-brand from the start. CEO: "This is what we talked about." Spent 1 hour tweaking (vs Durable's 3 hours fighting template constraints). Total time: 64 minutes vs Durable's 188 minutes. Extra 3.5 minutes of generation? Irrelevant. Final quality? Everything. Demo got approval, but result keeps client. Speed wins demos. Quality wins business.

THE AFTER

6 months later: client renewed contract, cited website quality as key factor. Sarah: "Durable got me the demo. Webflow got me the renewal. I don't care about 3.5 minutes. I care about results. Speed impressed them for 30 seconds. Quality impresses them every day." The lesson: choose based on output, not generation time. Speed is marketing. Quality is business.

THE 90-DAY BREAKDOWN

Month 1
Demo success
Month 2
Launched Webflow
Month 3
Client renewed

Speed won the demo (28 seconds). Quality won the business (ongoing). Choose wisely.

The Hard Truth

6 Speed Myths That Waste Your Time

"Fastest generation = fastest to launch"

Wrong. Durable generates in 28 seconds but takes 2-3 hours to customize. Webflow generates in 4 minutes but takes 1 hour to customize. Total time: Durable 128 min, Webflow 64 min. Fastest generator = slowest total. Speed metric is backwards.

"I need it in 30 seconds or I can't use it"

You don't launch in 30 seconds. You edit for hours. The 3-minute difference between Durable and Webflow is 2% of total time. If you have 2-4 hours to build, 3 minutes doesn't matter. Final quality does. Choose based on output, not generation speed.

"Speed is what I'm paying for"

Speed is a marketing hook, not a product. Durable's "30-second website" is technically true but practically meaningless. 30 seconds gets you generic template with AI filler. Real humans don't launch that. They edit. And editing takes 10x longer than generation.

"I don't have time to wait 3 minutes"

You have time to edit for 2-4 hours though. The 3-minute wait is 2% of total project time. If you're choosing based on saving 3 minutes, you're optimizing for the wrong thing. Optimize for final quality, not first impression speed.

"Faster generation means more iterations"

Only if you're A/B testing landing pages. For building one site to launch, you generate once, edit once. Speed advantage only matters for volume generation. Most people aren't doing that. They're building one site.

"Clients care how fast it generates"

Clients care about the result, not the process. Show them Durable's 30-second demo: "Cool." Show them Webflow's 4-minute result: "I want that." Speed wins the moment. Quality wins the business. Clients pay for outcomes, not generation time.

Unexpected Findings From Speed Testing 8 AI Builders

What nobody tells you about fast website generation

!

28-second generation, 2-hour edit: Durable reality

Durable generated complete site in 28 seconds. Homepage, services, about, contact—all sections filled with text. Then spent 2 hours fixing layout, changing colors, rewriting generic copy, replacing stock photos. Speed advantage: meaningless. You choose based on final quality, not generation speed.

!

4-minute generation, 1-hour edit: Webflow reality

Webflow took 4 minutes to generate initial layout. Design was beautiful—minimal, modern, on-brand. Spent 1 hour tweaking typography, adjusting spacing, swapping images. Total time: 64 minutes vs Durable's 128 minutes. Result: stunning vs functional. Extra 3.5 minutes of generation? Irrelevant.

!

"Need it today" = need it publishable, not generated

Client needed site launched same day. Used Durable: 28 seconds to generate, 3 hours to make it client-presentable. Could've used Webflow: 4 minutes to generate, 2 hours to better result. When "need it fast" means today, 3 minutes doesn't matter. Final quality does.

!

30-second marketing hook vs editing reality

Durable advertises "30-second websites." Technically true. But 30 seconds gets you a generic template with AI-written filler. Real humans don't launch that. They edit. And editing takes 10x longer than generation. Speed marketing creates false expectations.

!

Generation speed measured, editing time ignored

Every AI builder markets generation speed. None mention editing time. Measured total time-to-publish for identical project: Durable (128 min), Mixo (97 min), 10Web (84 min), Webflow (64 min). Fastest generator = slowest total. Slowest generator = fastest total. Speed metric is backwards.

!

Template constraints kill speed advantage

Durable generates fast but locks you into templates. Can't move sections. Can't change layout. Limited color themes. Fighting constraints takes hours. Webflow generates slower but everything is editable. Tweaking takes minutes. Speed advantage lost to inflexibility.

Quick reality check: I timed 8 AI website builders with identical prompts. Durable won at 28 seconds. Webflow took 4 minutes. But when I measured total time to publish-ready site, Webflow was 2x faster. The speed marketing? It's measuring the wrong thing.

The speed test nobody does

Test setup: Identical prompt, timer running

Created same prompt for 8 builders: "Marketing agency website with services, portfolio, team, contact." Started timer when I hit generate. Stopped when site was publish-ready (custom domain connected, content personalized, images replaced, mobile verified). Here's what actually happened.

Results (Total time to publish-ready):

  • Webflow: 4 min gen + 60 min edit = 64 min total
  • 10Web: 78 sec gen + 75 min edit = 76 min total
  • Squarespace: 148 sec gen + 90 min edit = 121 min total
  • Durable: 28 sec gen + 120 min edit = 128 min total

Why Durable takes longer despite being fastest

Durable's 28-second generation creates a complete site. But the design is locked into templates. Changing layout? Impossible. Moving sections? Can't do it. Color themes? Only 3 options. So you spend hours working within constraints, fighting the tool, compromising on design. Webflow's 4-minute generation creates a flexible foundation. Tweaking takes minutes because everything is editable.

The editing bottleneck nobody mentions

AI generates generic copy. "We provide exceptional services to help your business succeed." That's what Durable gave me. Real businesses don't talk like that. So you rewrite. You replace "exceptional services" with actual service names. You add real testimonials. You upload your team's photos. This takes 1-2 hours regardless of which tool you use. Generation speed is 5% of total time. It's marketed like it's 100%.

So when does speed actually matter?

Scenario 1: "I need to see something in 30 seconds"

Valid use case. You're pitching AI website building to a skeptic. You want to demo it live. You open Durable, type prompt, 28 seconds later: complete website on screen. The reaction: "Whoa." That moment of surprise has value. Durable wins demos.

Scenario 2: "I need a site launched today"

You have 8 hours. Generation speed is irrelevant. Even if you used Durable 16 times (one per hour), you'd spend all day editing. Time is better spent choosing based on final quality, not generation speed. For same-day launches, use the tool that produces the best result in 2-4 hours. That's Webflow, 10Web, or Squarespace.

Scenario 3: "I need to test 10 variations fast"

A/B testing landing pages. Here Durable's speed matters. Generate 10 variations in 5 minutes. Test traffic. Pick winner. Iterate. This is the one scenario where 30-second generation is a real advantage. But most people aren't doing this. They're building one site to launch.

Speed & Quality Comparison

Builder Gen Time Edit Time Total Quality
Durable 28s 120 min 128 min Basic
Mixo 35s 90 min 91 min Good
10Web 78s 75 min 76 min Better
Webflow 4 min 60 min 64 min Best

Choose Based on Your Situation

"I'm demoing AI to skeptics"

Use Durable. 28-second generation creates "whoa" moment. Perfect for live demos. The speed surprise wins people over instantly.

"I need a site launched today"

Use Webflow or 10Web. Generation speed doesn't matter when you're editing for hours. Better quality output = less editing time = faster to publish.

"I'm A/B testing landing pages"

Use Durable. Generate 10 variations in 5 minutes. Test traffic. Pick winner. This is the one scenario where 30-second generation is a real advantage.

"I want the best result"

Use Webflow. Extra 3.5 minutes of generation is irrelevant. Stunning design, full flexibility, professional output. Quality wins business, speed wins demos.

5-Step Decision Framework

1

Are you demoing or building?

Demo = Durable for "whoa" factor. Building = choose based on final quality, not generation speed.

2

How many variations do you need?

One site? Speed irrelevant. 10+ variations for A/B testing? Durable's speed matters.

3

What's your deadline?

Same-day launch? Use tool with best output in 2-4 hours (Webflow). Generation speed is 2% of total time.

4

Do you care about design quality?

Yes? Webflow produces stunning results. No? Durable is faster but generic-looking.

5

What's the stake: demo or business?

Demo = speed wins the moment. Business = quality wins long-term. Choose based on what matters.

FAQ

Which AI builder is fastest?

Durable generates sites in 28 seconds. Fastest by far. But total time to publish-ready is slower than Webflow (128 min vs 64 min). Fastest generation ≠ fastest to launch.

Does generation speed matter?

Only for demos and A/B testing. For building one site to launch, generation speed is 2% of total time. Editing is 98%. Choose based on output quality, not generation speed.

Why does Webflow take longer but finish faster?

Webflow takes 4 minutes to generate but only 1 hour to edit. Durable generates in 28 seconds but needs 2 hours to customize. Better initial output = less editing time = faster total.

When should I choose Durable?

Demoing AI to skeptics (28-second "whoa" moment). A/B testing landing pages (generate 10 variations in 5 minutes). For actual websites, choose based on final quality, not generation speed.

Is 30-second generation worth it?

Only if you're doing demos or A/B testing. For building one site, the 3-minute difference is irrelevant. You'll spend 2-4 hours editing regardless. Final quality matters more.

What's the total time to launch?

Durable: 28 sec gen + 120 min edit = 128 min total. Webflow: 4 min gen + 60 min edit = 64 min total. Fastest generator is slowest to launch. Slowest generator is fastest to launch.

Should I care about speed marketing?

No. Speed marketing measures generation time (5% of project). It ignores editing time (95% of project). Fastest generation is marketing hook, not practical advantage. Choose based on results, not process.

The Brutal Truth

AI builder speed is a marketing gimmick. Durable generates in 28 seconds but takes 2 hours to customize. Webflow generates in 4 minutes but takes 1 hour to customize. Total time: Durable 128 min, Webflow 64 min. Fastest generator = slowest total.

Generation speed is 2% of project time. Editing is 98%. Marketing makes it seem like speed is everything. Reality: speed is irrelevant for most use cases. Choose based on final quality, not generation time.

Speed wins demos. Quality wins business. Durable creates "whoa" moments in 28 seconds. Webflow creates stunning websites that impress clients for years. Which matters more?

Stop optimizing for generation speed. Start optimizing for final output. 3 minutes doesn't matter. Results do.

Things that drove me crazy

Speed ≠ Quality

30-second sites are functional, not amazing. Fast generation means basic templates.

Generation ≠ Launch

Even Durable takes 2-4 hours from start to publish-ready when you count editing.

Time perception

30 seconds vs 3 minutes doesn't matter in practice. You spend more time editing than generating.
